entry.title: Lake Ohau
entry.summary: After driving for hours it looks like Oahu. There isn't a single palm tree in sight, but the sign…
entry.content:
After driving for hours it looks like Oahu. There isn't a single palm tree in sight, but the sign for Lake Ohau sure had us thinking about Hawaii. The famous lakes of Aoraki / Mt. Cook needed our attention first, but something about a mysterious lake invisible from the highway lingered in our dreams that night in Twizel.

Maybe it was the frigid temperature in our box without heat. Maybe it was the shivering and rustling in our blankets, trying to ward off frozen toes and icy noses. Whatever the cause, the association of a mysterious lake with the warm tropical weather of Hawaii stirred our desires the next morning.

To say Lake Ohau is off the beaten path is an understatement. The fact that a sign exists, with several options for your traveling delights, seems to imply desperation for visitors. But with services beyond sight (17 km to the start of the lake, more if the ski resort is your end destination), few appear to ever set eyes on the lake.

The drive rolls gently over hills of golden grasslands, pulling the distant mountains closer to view with each passing dash of the roadway. After a few kilometers, we were satisfied with the mountain views, evoking the splendor of California's coastal mountains or the golden, dusty hue of the drive towards Death Valley.

Suddenly, the road both bends and drops, giving you the first glimpse of the lake and leaving you begging for more.

Framed by mountains on three sides and the valley you arrive in on the fourth, the desolate lake is also windswept. Wave after wave whipsaws the surface of Lake Ohau, pelting onlookers with a barrage of fresh air. Or, in winter, a breeze making you wonder whether it is possible to wear three gloves at once and appreciative of that hot cup of coffee you brought with you.

The rocks here lining the shore are ----,

You can imagine them tumbling down with the melting glaciers and tumbling against one another in the endless waves, coming to their rounded state quicker than many of the calmer glacial lakes of the world, or so it seems.

The road continues along the western, then northern side of the lake offering a few camping pullouts for presumably warmer days before morphing into a steep climb zig-zagging up the mountain range towards the ski resort at the top.

Looking back towards the valley, the aquamarine color of the lake is even more evident. The suns rays glistening off the 'rock flour' present in the water give a tint or hue spectacular even in comparison to the many beautiful lakes of the region.

As if the surprise needed more enjoyment, the drive back to the highway gave constant reminders of the valley's beauty in the mirrors.

entry.title: Mt. Aoraki & Lake Pukaki

entry.content:

entry.title: Wanaka
entry.summary: She didn't want to get up. She knew what was coming. She'd seen the mountains in the fading…
entry.content:
She didn't want to get up. She knew what was coming. She'd seen the mountains in the fading sun as we pulled into town the night before. Admittedly, they look intimidating. 

Some mountains go on forever, casually climbing to their heights, others race straight for the sky. These were skyscraper mountains.

Yet, a dense morning fog kept the peaks from view. Worried the blanket might extend all the way to the top, we nevertheless managed to leave our holiday park and make our way to the trailhead. 

Looking up, we could see reddish-orange puffs of grass (red tussock) in the frosty air, patches of leafy green succulents with thick, bumpy surfaces like green sandpaper, and a few unknown brushes poking up through the grassland. The chill air and thick fog kept our destination from view, leaving us to trod up the mountain, unclear of how far we truly had to go.

The fog gave the land the appearance of midwinter, the time at which the cold and lack of sunlight move from being a nuisance to feeling unbearable. Yet the sound of songbirds and occasional quail crossing the trail served to lift our spirits as we walked. And walked. And slipped. And walked more.

Red Tussock

 

Eat at The Cow

The tree, of course

and that peak.

entry.title: Milford Sound
entry.summary: The morning cruise was calm and quiet. The bathrooms foretold a different story in the summer months (picture…
entry.content:
The morning cruise was calm and quiet. The bathrooms foretold a different story in the summer months (picture a wall of 50 urinals to choose from). The valley receives almost daily rainfall, meaning the vast majority of tours take place under a blanket of clouds, with limited visibility. Most tourists don't mind, as the rain provides a series of waterfalls cascading down from the peaks and glaciers above. But, to get to watch the sun slowly rise over the peaks and see the full sound throughout the tour was a wonderful experience (I think I prefer the sunny day tour). I mean, there are still several beautiful waterfalls within the sound for viewing, even on dry days (with glaciers melting even in the winter today).

The sheer size of the sound is hard to fathom in photographs. 

The Encounter Nature Cruise was the longest offered in the winter season, so we signed up!

 

Mitre Peak stands watch over the land entrance to the sound, with boats similar to ours barely visible in the distance.

The boat meanders around the sound, often pulling right up next to the walls to get a closer look at the trees, the darker than dark water, and the sealife within the visible top layers (including starfish with eight arms).

The cliffs are interesting rock faces which glisten with color in the sunlight. The rocks at the edge of the sound give a glimpse into their composition.

Stirling Falls teases the eye from a distance for the first quarter of the trip, gradually coming closer and closer as you make your way out towards the open sea.

The colors change throughout the morning as the sun alters the appearance of the landscape. Full of shadows and dark greys in the early morning, a blueish-green takes over soon after, highlighting the vegetation which covers every possible inch of the steep cliffs.

The boat we chose offered indoor and outdoor seating, with minimal movement on the smooth morning waters. While the deck clearly afforded the best views, the chilling temperatures and incredibly cold breeze off the Tasman Sea were far from ideal. Though it did mean a nearly empty outdoor area to move about and take in the incredible views!

Upon reaching the open sea the waters quickly turn a brilliant light blue, the sun can be seen with all its splendor, the water becomes choppy, and the wind seems to pull the gloves off your hands. Though the entrance to the sound may be its most striking feature.

The return trip included passing by a favority resting place of New Zealand Fur Seals on the way to an up close encounter with the waterfall we'd been watching all morning.

For brave, hearty souls, the tour offers a 'glacial facial'. You can stand at the front of the boat as it sails into the cascade of water from the glacier above. My kind of facial!

After getting doused with bone-chillingly cold water, the tour is nearly over. After arriving back at the dock, we disembarked and headed over for overpriced lunch, though with the view of the sound included, perhaps it was underpriced!

entry.title: Fiordland National Park
entry.summary: Many of these are still in the Milford Sound valley (river, waterfalls, drive up to the tunnel). So maybe…
entry.content:
Many of these are still in the Milford Sound valley (river, waterfalls, drive up to the tunnel). So maybe tell story of road to the tunnel (Kea, blue early mountains, Gunn Lake) & from tunnel to the sound separately.

Leaving the sound, back through the tunnel (and into Kea land!)

entry.title: Most Scenic Commuter Flight, Ever.
entry.summary: Flight from Auckland to Queenstown. The most beautiful flight in the world? I thought it was over the…
entry.content:
Flight from Auckland to Queenstown. The most beautiful flight in the world? I thought it was over the Grand Canyon. Then I thought it was into Seattle with views of Rainier and St. Helens. Nope, it's this one.

South Island

entry.title: Waitomo Caves
entry.summary: The stars glisten a calming shade of light blue, sitting at the expanse of your vision. As your…
entry.content:
The stars glisten a calming shade of light blue, sitting at the expanse of your vision. As your guide slowly paddles the boat through the gentle waters, a cool breeze gently sweeps across the bow as everyone silently stares at the expanse.

The tiny lights in the distance appear similar to our celestial night sky to the naked eye at water level, but closer inspection brings a host of surprises. Far from stars, those calm lights are instead part of the ruse of a fisherman on the ceiling, looking for dinner.

It truly is a sight to see, thousands of glow worms attached to the ceiling, each with their own plot to fish from. Tourists come from the world over to take a guided tour in one of several locations throughout New Zealand, though the Waitomo caves are the most well-known. 

The bioluminescent glow may be the highlight of most cave tours, but a guided walk through a separate cave offers an up-close look at the lines these creatures lay to catch their prey.

To learn more about these magnificent creatures, and see them in action, check out the video: https://vimeo.com/356649644.

Ruakuri Cave

After the classic boat tour through the caverns filled with glow worms we had the chance to explore a separate cave on foot. Filled with incredible formations, from drapery folds, to popcorn, to entire ceilings of stalactites, this second cave provided some of the most beautiful natural cave art we've seen.
